text: LONG SHOT of the solitary figure of a WOMAN standing  professionally alone at the end of the street. It is a bright, still night. We can HEAR the Woman whistl 'Stardust' merrily to herself. CAMERA TRACKS around her. A Man's footsteps are overlaid. We HEAR the Man start to whistle 'Stardust' under his bre haltingly at first, then in time with the Woman. As we approach, she glances at us over her shoulder - the turns round for a better look. Her whistling stops - so, at the same moment, does the  man's. CLOSE SHOT of DORA - a plump, attractive brunette - still young enough to need two glances at the customers. She smiles at us - and is pleased with the reception. She hesitates for a long moment, weighing us up carefully...  and then - half defiantly, half expecting to be laughed  at.
It'll be two quid...

Evidently we have two quid.   She beams with relief - throws her fur over her shoulders jerks her head towards the right - and sets off. CAMERA TRACKS after her.  Overlaid is the sound of the  man's footsteps. Dora resumes her whistling. So, under his breath, does th man who is following her.

A wider street than the last - but just as empty.   Dora sways her way towards a small house. CAMERA FOLLOWS  at a respectful distance. CAMERA PANS from Dora's hips to an overflowing dustbin.   CLOSE SHOT of a man's hand throwing something into the  dustbin. It is an empty packet marked Kodak Film.  CAMERA PANS to Dora's house. It stands next to a chemist shop. Dora climbs the few steps which lead to her front door -  glances round at us encouragingly - then unlocks the door

She switches on a light - and hurries up a flight of stai CAMERA TRACKS after her. She changes her tune to 'Goodnight Sweetheart'... and so under his breath - does the Man who is following her.   A woman with hair like a two-toned car comes down the  stairs, winks at Dora - looks at us for a moment with gre curiosity... winks... then passes out of camera. Dora reaches the landing - we are close behind her.
Dora unlocks the door of her room - and goes inside.

She switches on the light, throws her fur onto a chair,  lights the gas fire  then turns round. CLOSE SHOT of Dora. She holds out her hand-smiling. And suddenly. There is a gentle whirring purring sound. CAMERA HOLDS ON Dora - she is staring at something with  great curiosity. It turns quickly to bewilderment - and the bewilderment t fear. She steps back from CAMERA - but CAMERA won't have  it. Dora is now staring at something in horror - she opens he mouth to scream - a shadow falls across her face. The sound purrs on.

The solitary figure of Dora standing professionally alone at the end of a street. WE SEE her turn towards CAMERA -  and smile at us. We are watching her on a 16mm screen - projected in BLACK AND WHITE. CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the surround in natural colour.

A darkened room in natural COLOUR. The movie screen image are in BLACK AND WHITE.   We can SEE the back of a Man's head as he bends intently  over a projector. He is watching Dora on the screen. He i breathing quickly. We see Dora's hips waggling their way home. The Man raises his head, so that we cannot see the screen When he lowers it again, we see the Woman with the two- toned hair winking at Dora... then we see Dora throwing  her fur onto a chair - and turning towards us. WE SEE her staring at something in bewilderment... then  backing away from CAMERA in fear. WE HEAR the Man breathing as if at the end of a very long race. As Dora opens her mouth to scream, and a shadow falls acr her face - the title:
Blots out what is happening to her. OTHER CREDITS FOLLOW... behind them we can see Dora's han pushing something away. Before the DIRECTOR'S CREDIT:

It is very dark. CLOSE SHOT of a stack of deck chairs. Two forms behind it - a MAN'S and a WOMAN'S. They are intertwined and motionless... suddenly a brillia shaft of light is trained onto them. Overlaid is a gentle, whirring sound. CAMERA PANS quickly to a nearby tree. CLOSE SHOT of the lens of a cine-camera - the motor  purring... a blinding spotlight. CAMERA PANS to the couple - the whirring of the camera is overlaid. The Man leaps up - shielding his eyes against the light. He advances towards the tree.
Hey, you peeping...
The spotlight goes out. There is the sound of footsteps  running away  and the night is at peace again. And now WE SEE who DIRECTED the picture.
It is standing in the roadway outside Dora's house. WE SEE it through the finder of a small cine-camera.

A crowd has gathered outside the house - and we are watch them from a corner of the street (ALWAYS THROUGH THE FIND MATTE). WE SEE several Policemen holding back the crowd as two  Ambulance Men hurry into the house, carrying an empty  stretcher. Gentle, whirring sound is overlaid. WE SEE children staring curiously into the empty ambulanc and a group of Women talking excitedly to a Reporter. CLOSE SHOT of a SMALL MAN looking at us curiously as he  approaches (FILLING THE SCREEN WITHIN THE MATTE).
What paper are you from?

The finder is lowered. CLOSE SHOT of a Young Man (MARK) sighting a cine-camera.  He lowers the camera - and turns politely to his  interrogator. He seems to have slight difficulty informing his words.
I beg your pardon?
What paper are you from?
Mark smiles at him pleasantly.
The Observer.

The Ambulance Men come out of the house carrying the  stretcher... there is a body on it covered by a sheet.   Mark raises his cine-camera and photographs them. He  photographs the ambulance as it drives off. He photograph the Policemen dispersing the crowd. He photographs his  Interrogator, who gladly poses for him. Then he slings his camera over his shoulder, and strolls  away.

CLOSE SHOT of Dora, smiling happily.   Her photograph is on the front page of a newspaper.   Above it is a caption: BRUTALLY MURDERED.   CAMERA PULLS BACK - to show sexy magazines alongside the  newspaper.

Mark is staring at a newspaper in the window of a small  newsagent's shop.   He glances distastefully at an array of film magazines -  showing actresses showing everything - then hurries into  the shop.
A plump, bald-headed Man stares at Mark.
You're late!
Sorry, sir.
He turns towards a small door at the end of the shop.
(quietly) Hold on, Mark.
Mark turns round. Mr. Peters hesitates, drumming his fingers on the counter CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He starts to drum his fingers on a  shelf.
Mark... I've a question for you.
He stops drumming his fingers. So, at that moment, does  Mark.
Which magazines sell the most  copies?
Those with girls on the front covers -  and no front covers on the girls.
Exactly!... And it's just the same  with the work you do for me.
Overlaid is the sound of the door opening.
Look busy.
Mark busies himself sorting some newspapers.  A whole row of Doras smile up at him. CAMERA PANS to doorway of the shop. An ELDERLY GENTLEMAN is standing there.
The Times, please.
Certainly, sir.
And The Telegraph.
Certainly, sir - anything else?
The Elderly Gentleman hesitates - glancing at Mark's back Then:
I... er... have been told by a  friend that you... er... have some  views for sale?
What sort of views, sir?
Well, er...
This sort, sir?
From under the counter he produces a thick book. Mark tur round. From his POV WE SEE the Elderly Gentleman open the book.  He - er- seems - er - more than a little interested.
I, er... how much each?
Five shillings, sir.
I'll take this one... and, er...  this one... and, er... how much  would the lot be?
To you - five pounds, sir...
The Elderly Gentleman hesitates.  Mr. Peters turns over a page... and the Elderly Gentleman almost turns over with  it.
Tell you what, sir. Four pounds  ten - and I'll throw in The Times  and Telegraph... how's that?
Well, er... thank you very much.
Let me wrap it for you, sir.
He puts it in a wrapper which says 'Educational Books'.
Shall I put you on our mailing  list?
Oh no! But I'll look in again...
By all means, sir.
He holds open the door for the Elderly Gentleman, and  watches him leave.
He won't be doing the crossword  tonight!
He turns triumphantly to Mark.
(counting out money  from wallet) Those pictures he chose... were  all yours! (handing notes) This is yours!
Mark pockets them without counting them.  CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
(in a very different  tone) And this is yours too...
He picks up a postcard - holds it towards Mark.
And that's what I want to talk to  you about. It's a clever picture -  because you're a clever lad...  but, Mark... (pathetically) It's all face.
Mark looks at the postcard in silence.
I don't want to hurt your feelings,  son - but if people want the Mona  Lisa they go to the National  Gallery.
The Louvre.
Well, wherever they go, they don't  come here... so no more of this  fancy stuff...
He pats Mark's arm.
... now get upstairs - the girls  are waiting... and so is a bonus  if you give me what I want.
Thank you, sir.
(amused) What do you do with all your money?
Buy cameras.
He opens a door at the far end of the room. We catch a  glimpse of a winding staircase. He starts to climb it.
At the top of the staircase is a door. Mark and his camer trudge towards it. The door opens suddenly. A vivacious  young redhead - Milly - pokes her head round. She has a  towel round her shoulders.
Well look who's here! Cecil Beaton!
From REVERSE ANGLE WE SEE Mark venture a shy smile at Mil Milly opens the door impatiently.
Come on, sonny... make us famous.

Through the half-open door we catch a glimpse of a second Girl (LORRAINE). She is staring out of a window, her back to camera. She is naked except for a shawl draped round  her shoulders.   Mark enters the room... the door begins to close. CAMERA  TRACKS towards the door. On the threshold of the room, a  hood is thrown over our faces. THE SCREEN BLACKS OUT. In the darkness WE HEAR Milly's voice.
Did you read about that girl who  was murdered last night?
We are with Mark under the hood of an antiquated camera.  Through the ground-glass of the camera WE SEE a SMALL  INVERTED IMAGE of Milly.
The same thing nearly happened to  me!
We hear Lorraine's voice - muffled, and very far away.
When?
Last night! I went out with my  boyfriend... We're getting married  next month... trouble was my fiance  saw us.
The SMALL INVERTED IMAGE of Milly peers anxiously into th camera.
can you fix it so the bruises don't  show?

The ground-glass camera begins travelling slowly down  Milly's back. CLOSE SHOT of Milly. She is on a couch, lying on her stom at a slightly oblique angle. All that WE CAN SEE are her  face and naked shoulders. From Milly's POV WE SEE Mark under the hood of an antiqua camera.
Well, can you?
Mark's voice is MUFFLED under the hood.
...think so, Milly.
Then be quick about it, sonny! I'm  freezing.

CLOSE SHOT of her naked toes. They start to wriggle.   CLOSE SHOT of Mark's toes - in sandals, next to the tripo of the camera. They start to wriggle.  CLOSE SHOT of Lorraine. We watch her in profile as she  stares out of the window - clutching her shawl. She has  outstandingly beautiful features.  CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He is standing by the side of the  camera, studying us thoughtfully. He is holding a remote- control switch panel in his hand. He clicks off several  lights and then switches several others on... then he duc back under the hood.
There he goes again! What have you  got under there? A girlfriend?
We join Mark under the hood.   WE SEE a small INVERTED IMAGE of Milly on the ground-glas Her shoulders are now white and glistening, her spine  caressed by shadows. She is staring into the camera.
I suppose you have a girlfriend?
He adjusts the focus. We can see more clearly the contemp on Milly's face.
No, Milly.
Hear that, Lorraine? He's available.
From Milly's POV WE SEE Mark come round to the front of  the camera, and insert a dark slide.
Raise your head, please - and look  at the sea.
What sea?
Mark presses a rubber bulb - the shutter clicks.
What sea?
Mark inserts another dark slide.
I just wanted that puzzled look.
Oh, did you? Well if you want it  again, I'll think of you!
from Milly's viewpoint, WE SEE Mark holding the rubber  bulb. cine-camera is on a ledge behind him.
You're a puzzle and a half.
Mark presses the rubber bulb - the shutters click.
This is a spare time job for you,  isn't it?
Yes, Milly.
He inserts another slide.
Well, what do you do for a living?
Take pictures.
He presses the bulb - the shutters click.
This sort?
No, Milly.
He inserts another slide.
Don't you like this sort?
No, Milly.
He presses the bulb - the shutters click.
Well what sort do you like?
Mark looks at her thoughtfully for a long moment.
I may show you - one day.
That'll be a treat, I'm sure.
Mark smiles at her shyly.
That's all, Milly.
Oh no, sonny! Now take one I can  show my mother.
Mark inserts another slide.
Think of her then.
There is a gentle KNOCK at the door, and Mr. Peters enter He carries a tray of coffee. He keeps his eyes modestly  lowered.
On the house.
He lays the tray on a table, still keeping his eyes lower and goes out.
Some house! Hope it falls on his  ruddy earhole!
She glances over her shoulder.
It's your turn now, love...
CLOSE SHOT of Lorraine staring out of the window. She  stiffens. Milly's voice is overlaid.
(in a whisper) ... it's her first time.
Lorraine clutches her shawl tightly.
Come on, love. Don't be shy.

Lorraine turns round.   The left side of her face is classical in its beauty. She has a hare lip, which twists and distorts the whole of th right side. Her eyes are large - and beautiful - and  defiant. CLOSE SHOT of Mark looking at her. CLOSE SHOT of Lorraine.
He said... you needn't photograph  my face!
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
I want to.
CLOSE SHOT of Lorraine. Beautiful in profile.
I suppose you'll fix my bruises  too?
I want to...
What about the customers?
CLOSE SHOT of the shawl round Lorraine's shoulders. CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
You needn't be shy... of me...  it's my first time too.
CLOSE SHOT of Lorraine's eyes - puzzled.
Yours?
In front of eyes... like...
He tries to go on - but words are a foreign language to  him.
...eyes... as full of...
In a sudden rush:
Lorraine - let my camera tell you.

CLOSE SHOT of Lorraine standing very still  looking at  him in silence. Milly shrugs and reaches for the coffee pot. Overlaid is the gentle purring of a cine-camera. CAMERA LINGERS on the dark liquid being poured into a cup
Whisky being poured into a glass.

The hand filling the glass is a woman's (MRS. STEPHENS).  She is sitting in a high-backed chair, and we cannot see  her face. Over her shoulder we watch a party in progress. A group of Young people have surrounded someone to whom  they are singing:
(singing) Happy birthday to you,  Happy birthday to you,
CAMERA TRACKS towards them. CLOSE SHOT of TONY HUNTER, a well-built youngster in his  middle twenties.
Happy birthday... dear Helen
He obviously means it.
happy birthday to you.
CLOSE SHOT of 'dear HELEN'. A sensitive, intelligent, and extremely attractive girl, who  as the encircling  youngsters now inform us in song - is:
Twenty-one today, She's twenty-one today, She's got the key of the door, She's never been twenty-one before.
CLOSE SHOT of the glass by Mrs. Stephens' side. It is hal empty. An elderly lady leans across to her. She is Mrs.  Partridge, slightly high on a glass of sherry.
You must be very proud of your  daughter, Mrs. Stephens.
Mrs. Stephens grunts. Someone switches on a gramophone an the young couples start dancing at once. Tony hurries up  to Helen.
May I?
Helen goes towards him. A YOUNG MAN calls out sharply:
Look!

He is pointing at something out of camera. All heads -  except Mrs. Stephens' - follow the direction of his gaze. Mrs. Stephens continues to sit motionless in the high-bac chair. CAMERA PANS to the window. Mark is standing there. CLOSE SHOT of Helen looking at Mark. We watch him over he shoulder - Tony's arm encircling it.
It's that chap from upstairs.

The chap from upstairs presses his face to the window.  From his POV WE SEE Helen's eyes looking at him - the key of the door in them - looking at him, not staring. Sudden the rest comes into focus - Tony's arm around Helen's  shoulder... the high-backed chair in the foreground with  the back of that motionless head... a young couple giggli as they stare at him. Mark steps away, and the CAMERA PUL BACK with him. We catch a glimpse of the house - large, sprawling, but  with a touch of quality about it, in a quiet, unpretentio street. Mark hurries towards a side entrance.
CLOSE SHOT of Helen looking at the empty window.
I'll ask him in...
CLOSE SHOT of Tony - frowning. CAMERA PANS to Mrs. Stephens' glass... the hand which  refills it has begun to tremble.
The lights are on. WE FOLLOW Mark (and his camera) along a small passage whi leads to the hall. The sound of a dance record can be hea Mark starts to whistle it under his breath.

Over his shoulder we see a staircase, and beyond it the  door of Helen's sitting room. The sound of Helen's party  fills the hall. Mark reaches the staircase. There is the sound of a door  opening. Helen's voice is overlaid:
Excuse me!
Mark hesitates, then turns round.  CLOSE SHOT of Helen - smiling at him.
I don't know how many times we've  passed each other on the stairs?
Mark looks at her as if he does.
... but tonight I'm determined at  least to say hello to you! So hello!
Her directness is natural, consistent and very hard to  resist. CLOSE SHOT of Mark - smiling.
I'm Helen Stephens.
She glances with unconcealed interest at the camera over  his shoulder.
I'm having a party - and the other  tenants are there...  And a few  friends. We'd like you to join us.
Mark...
Pardon?
I'm Mark...
Hallo, Mark.
She holds out her hand... he takes it gently.
Please come in... you'll meet the  others who live here, and...
Thank you, but... work.
Oh...
She glances again at his camera.
Well, I hope to keep it going for  hours yet... so when you've finished  why not look in?
She realizes that this is not the happiest of phrases.
...Mark?
He hesitates.  CAMERA PANS to Helen's door. Tony stands there.
Darling, your cake - everyone's  waiting.
CLOSE SHOT of Mark - looking at her.
Thank you.
He turns away.
Happy Birthday.
He hurries up the stairs. CLOSE SHOT of Helen. She stares after him for a moment.  Then returns thoughtfully to her party.
The screen remains dark for a moment. We are with Mark in a darkened room. He is giving a film show - and we are th screen.

His cine-projector points straight at us.  A flickering  light shines in our eyes. We can see him crouching behind the projector. Mark leans forward, watching the screen intently...  Perspiration trickles down his forehead. He is breathing  very quickly. The sounds of the party seep up from  downstairs - music, laughter, and a Girl's yelp. There is a knock on the door. Mark does not hear it.   CAMERA PANS to the door of the room. It is blacked-out  like a photographic dark-room. The knock is repeated.   CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He switches off the projector instant CAMERA PANS to an open cupboard in the corner. CLOSE SHOT of the shelves. They are stacked with spools o film. CAMERA travels slowly over these spools. WE SEE Mark's  hand add two more to the collection; his Voice is overlai
...minute...
He closes the cupboard door.

Mark comes out of the dark-room behind him - the light is kept out by a baffle and a curtain. He has a pleasant,  normally untidy bedsitting room. He wipes his handkerchief across his forehead - then hurr to the door. He opens it - Helen is standing there.
I hope I'm not disturbing you?
CLOSE SHOT of Mark - shaking his head, smiling shyly. CLOSE SHOT of Helen.
I knew you wouldn't come down...  so I've brought you this.
She holds out a plate on which is a piece of birthday cak
Thank you...
He takes the plate.
... very much...
I mustn't keep you from your work
She turns to go.
I'd like to offer you a drink.
She turns round.
Thank you, Mark.
I haven't one.
I'd adore some water.
She smiles.
a hostess can't drink water at her  own party, it looks like a hint to  the guests.
Will you... would you... like to  come in?
Yes, Mark...
She steps over the threshold. The door closes behind her.
CLOSE SHOT of Helen looking round the room. Mark's voice is overlaid.
There's milk... if you'd like some?
Very much... if you can spare it?
Yes.
Helen glances towards the inner room. He holds out a glas of milk to her.
Thank you, Mark...
She drinks it with relish. He watches her in silence.
This is a pleasant room... and  you've another inside?
Yes.
How long have you lived here?
All my life.
She looks at him in surprise.
I was born in this house Oh?
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
It's my father's.
Do you mean I've at last found out  who our landlord is? Your father?
Well - no... he's dead!
He hesitates.
I'm the landlord.
She looks at him in astonishment.
YOU?
Yes.
But you walk about as if you haven't  paid the rent.
I haven't.
I meant...
I know.
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
It's his house - and I'll never  sell it... but I can't afford the  upkeep, so I let rooms.
He looks at her anxiously.
... if I charge too much, tell me  and I'll tell the agents.
The rent's very reasonable, but  don't say anything to the others  or you'll have no peace.
Peace...?
CLOSE SHOT of Helen.
Mark, what do you do?
(slowly) Most of the time, I work in a film  studio.
On the photographic side, I'll  bet.
I hope to be a film director...  very soon.
How exciting.
I have some spare time jobs... as  well.
To do with photography?
More milk?
No thank you... to do with  photography?
Yes... to do with photography...
When I came in were you looking at  some films?
Yes.
Of yours?
Yes.
I'd like to see them...
He looks at her in silence.
Know I'm being rude... but I really  would like to see them... (she smiles.) ...it would be a birthday present...  from you to me.
Would it?
Yes, Mark.
Oh...
But I suppose you're too busy?
She puts down the glass, turns to the door.
Will you... would you... like to  see them now?
She turns round. He is standing by the entrance to the  inner room.
Thank you...
I'll... go first.
He leads the way - she follows. For a moment the screen i in darkness. A dark-room darkness.

We can HEAR - faintly  the dance music from downstairs.   There is a click - and the walls are suddenly bathed in  diffused light, throwing the room into delicate shadow.  CLOSE SHOT of Helen looking round in amazement. As certain events of possible interest are to take place  in this room, here, in detail, is what amazes Helen. The room is the product of three rooms which have been  knocked into one. It is very large and extremely well  constructed (as we are soon to learn, it was originally a laboratory). One half of the room is used for processing, and the other half for filming - and for trade shows. The two halves are lined by long shelves upon which are perch all shapes and sizes of cameras, their spectacles glintin in the light. In the processing half two benches (a 'dry' bench and a  'wet' bench) face each other against opposite walls. Ther are three sinks above the 'wet' bench and an outburst of  equipment above the 'dry'. This part of the room is lit by two dark-room lamps frown in the ceiling above the benches. The other part of the room has a window at the far end of it. Heavy drapes are putted across it. Mark's projector rests on a small table in front of the  16mm screen.  Two banks of floods and a variety of spots  light this part of the room. There is a small control pan on the wall.   Some of the equipment is ancient - but none of it is old. All of it glistens with the affection of its owner. There is absolutely nothing in the room to alarm anyone  except an adult... the kind who starts to wonder who paid for it all. CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He stands by the lighting panel,  watching Helen. From his POV WE SEE her brushing the hair out of her eyes as she looks slowly round. He brushes the hair out of his For a moment she turns her back to him. He presses a swit on the wall. A gentle light ripples through the back of  Helen's hair. SHOT of Helen. She turns to him. She is very nearly at a  loss for words.
This is so... well - so many  things... but above all - it's  so...
She takes a final look round.
...completely unexpected!
She looks at him searchingly.
Is all of it yours?
Yes.
I mean... is it designed by you?  Furnished by you? Tell me about  this room.
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
It belonged to my father
What was he?
Scientist...
Then this equipment was his?
No...
He hesitates.
Sold his to buy it...
But it seems to be so... technical.
She looks at him with renewed interest.
If this is where you work, I can't  wait to see what you work at.
CLOSE SHOT of Mark - in difficulties.
Don't know what to show you?
Well... what were you looking at  when I interrupted you?
He looks at her thoughtfully.
All right!

He crosses to the corner cupboard - opens the door. CLOSE SHOT of the cupboard.  WE SEE Mark's hand reach for a spool of film... then hesitate, poised above another  spool. CLOSE SHOT of Helen - watching with interest. REVERSE ANGLE SHOT of Mark. He closes the cupboard, and  turns round... there is a spool of film in his hand. He walks slowly towards his projector... he seems  for  the moment  to have forgotten she is there. CLOSE SHOT of Helen - watching him thread the film into  the projector.
This is the first... twenty-first  birthday present... I'll ever have  given.
It's the first I've ever asked  for...

He places a chair a few feet away from the screen - and,  with an oddly courteous bow, beckons her into it. She sit down. CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He looks at her intently for a moment then turns off the lights. Over Helen's shoulder We can  just make out the empty screen. Mark switches on the  projector. CLOSE SHOT of Helen - the light flickering on her face.  CLOSE SHOT of Mark staring at Helen's face. CLOSE SHOT of Helen. WE SEE her expression of surprise.  Over Mark's shoulder WE SEE the surprise growing. Over  Helen's shoulder we see the screen. We are looking at a  small boy. He is lying in his bed asleep. Although the  print is old, we can see that he is a remarkably handsome boy.
Mark, what a beautiful child.
The boy turns restlessly in his sleep... one of his pillo falls to the floor.
Who is he?
Me
Of course it is!  Then who took  this film?
(quietly) My Father.
A light - as if from a small torch  starts to shine on  the child's eyes. He moves restlessly.
What a wonderful idea...
The light plays on the child's left eye, then on his righ It is growing brighter.
You'll be able to show it to your  own chi...
The child wakes up suddenly. He stares at something...  then starts to scream.
You must have had a bad dream...
CLOSE SHOT of Mark watching her in silence.
...but what was that light?  ...The  camera, I suppose?

Mark does not answer. The small screen is filled with the face of the screaming, terrified child. (Mark's father now tries a not altogether successful  dissolve:) WE NOW SEE the little boy standing in front of a garden  wall. He tries hard to climb to the top of the wall, but  falls over. Helen laughs. Mark watches her in silence.  Small Mark tries again - and again - to scale the wall... At last he succeeds.
Whatever are you after?

WE SEE the little boy lying flat on the wall staring at  something... rapt, motionless.   The cine-camera which is taking this picture now tracks  rather clumsily towards the wall. HIGH ANGLE SHOT over the wall of what is fascinating youn Mark - A man and woman are lying on the ground, kissing.  The CINE-CAMERA PANS - again rather clumsily - to young  Mark... staring intently.
Naughty boy I hope you were spanked!
CLOSE SHOT of Helen. It suddenly occurs to her.
... but, Mark... what a strange  thing for your father to photograph.
Switch off?
No.
She stares again at that lonely figure perched on the wal
No.
The small screen begins to dissolve ...so does the large  one.
Over Mrs. Stephens' shoulder WE SEE the party in progress The glass by her side is full again. Tony is dancing with an attractive blonde.
Tony!
He turns round.
Me, Mrs. Stephens?

The head nods. Tony advances reluctantly towards her. REVERSE ANGLE SHOT of Mrs. Stephens. Over Tony's shoulder WE SEE a powerfully built and once  lovely woman. She is so perpetually drunk as almost to be sober. The fe movements she makes are slow - deliberate - and give noth away. The voice articulates so carefully that the slur  scarcely shows. The fact that she is blind almost helps to conceal the  fact that she is drunk. Her sightless eyes stare out the  camera as Tony reaches her.
I want a word with you.
CLOSE SHOT of Helen's eyes. The light from the projector  flickering into them.
I hate people who chatter in films -  but there's so much I want to ask.

She is leaning forward, her face cupped in her hand,  watching the small screen intently. CLOSE SHOT of Mark. His face is cupped in his hand as he  watches her intently. Over Helen's shoulder WE SEE Mark in the making. The child is again asleep... this time he is being  photographed from the head of the bed - the CAMERA POINTI STRAIGHT DOWN AT HIS FACE. A beam of light starts to shine onto his eyes, first onto the left, then onto the right.
(in a whisper) Again?

Mark looks at her in silence. The boy moves restlessly, then turns over onto his face,  pulling the bedclothes round him. His right hand is limp  on the pillow. The light shines for a moment on this hand then goes out.  Helen half turns towards Mark.
Mark, this isn't some kind of jo...
Her attention is suddenly riveted on the screen.
(in a whisper) No, Helen.
Over Helen's shoulder WE SEE something drop onto the chil bed... something which stays quite still for a moment,  then starts crawling towards the counterpane. It is a sma lizard.
Mark, whatever is that?

Her voice trails away. She stares - repelled and fascinat at the screen. WE SEE Mark reach for his cine-camera.  Over Helen's shoulder WE SEE the lizard reach the  counterpane. It stretches itself out on the floral design its body is pointed towards the child's hand. WE HEAR a click - and suddenly a spotlight falls onto  Helen's face. OVERLAID is the GENTLE PURRING of Mark's cine-camera. She wheels towards him - blotting out the small screen.
What are you...
wanted to photograph you...  watching...
No, Mark!
The camera purrs on.
No!
He switches off the spot... the purring of the camera die away. She turns towards the small screen.
help me to understand this... this  nightmare...

The small boy is sitting upright... screaming with terror there is no sign of the lizard. A handkerchief is thrown onto the boy's bed. He continues crying - looking up into someone's face. CLOSE SHOT of Mark watching the screen. We hear a man's deep voice overlaid.
That'll do Mark... dry your eyes  and stop being silly.
Small Mark reaches for the handkerchief and wipes his  eyes... his hands are trembling. The small screen trembles with them into a clumsy dissolv Helen turns to Mark.
All right... now look... Mark -  what was all that about?
He looks at her helplessly.
... that was a lizard, wasn't it?  Or a...
Liz...
Well how did it get there?... How  did it get there Mark?...  Was it  a pet?
Not mine...
Won't you try to explain?
CLOSE SHOT of Mark staring at the screen.
You'd better go!
I like to understand what I'm shown!
She turns to the screen.
What was your father trying to  do?... Photographing you at nigh...
Her voice trails away.
better go...

From Helen's POV WE SEE the screen. Small Mark is wearing a dark suit and a black tie. He is standing at the foot of a four-poster bed, staring  at something in horror and disbelief... his hands clasp  the bedrail tightly. Slowly - very slowly - he walks towards the head of the  bed, staring. His lips begin to quiver. He bends forward over the bed.  WE CAN SEE the back of his bowed head.
Mark... what is this?
I am saying... goodbye... my  mother...
We catch a glimpse of a woman's hands folded in front of  her. CLOSE SHOT of Helen.
(in a whisper) He... photographed... that...?
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
Yes.
Suddenly - and healthily - his temper snaps.
...and this!
He pushes a lever on his projector as far forward as it  will go. The film is now shown at tremendous speed - We catch a  glimpse of a long line of cars.
...her funeral!
It speeds by.
...and this!
A confused picture of earth and flowers.
...her burial!
The briefest glimpse of a little boy with a spade.
...and this!
WE SEE a girl in a bikini by sand-dunes. Mark offers no  comment.
Mark, who is that?
Her successor.
CLOSE SHOT of Helen.
Suc-?
He married her... six weeks after...  the previous sequence.

He pulls back the lever of his projector... the film retu to its normal speed. WE SEE the same attractive young woman standing in a gard She is holding a bewildered and defiant Mark by the hand. Suddenly the girl runs towards camera - leaving Mark  standing alone.
She filmed... what comes now.
CLOSE SHOT of Helen watching intently.  It's out of focus From Helen's POV WE SEE a tall man in a black coat walkin away from camera. He hurries towards small Mark - who  watches him anxiously.
Is that your father?
The morning that he left for his  honeymoon.

The back of Mark's father suddenly obscures our view of  small Mark... all we can see is that tall figure looking  downwards standing very still. Camera wobbles - as if the person holding it is laughing.
What is he doing?
Giving me a present...
What was it?
Mark stares at the blurred screen, perspiration trickling down his forehead.
Can't you guess?

The small screen comes back into focus - and suddenly our camera rushes towards it. WE SEE a CLOSE SHOT of a CLOSE SHOT - and at the moment w see it, Mark's Voice is overlaid... A whisper which echoe round the room.
A camera...

We are looking at a close shot of a camera in a small boy hands. There is a single shrill chord of music on the sound trac CLOSE SHOT of the shelf which encircles Mark's room.   We are looking at the very same camera which the small bo is holding. CLOSE SHOT of the camera in small Mark's hands. His father's finger points lo the view-finder. Small Mark stares into it. Small Mark begins to smile. CLOSE SHOT of Mark watching himself being born. CLOSE SHOT of Helen watching Mark.
Switch it off!
He continues to stare at the screen.
Switch it off, Mark!

She turns to the projector - touches the wrong switch. Small Mark and his father go rapidly backwards. Mark turns off the projector abruptly.  The room is in darkness. WE CAN HEAR both of them breathing quickly.  The light goes on. Mark is standing by the exit - he keep his face averted. Helen walks slowly towards the exit. She glances round  once, over her shoulder, then goes into the other room.  Mark stares after her.
She walks towards the door... turns round suddenly - almo in anger.
So he was a scientist?
He keeps his face averted.
What kind of scientist, Mark?
Biologist.
What was he trying to do to you?
He doesn't answer.
Mark!...
He turns round slowly. From his POV WE SEE the willingnes to understand on her face.
What was he trying to do to you?
Watch me... grow up...
She walks towards him... takes his handkerchief from his  jacket pocket and wipes his forehead.
He wanted a record of a growing  child... complete in every detail -  if such a thing were possible -  and he tried to make it possible  by training a camera on me... at  all times...
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
I never knew... the whole of my  childhood... one moment's privacy...
And those lights in your eyes?...  and that - thing?
He was interested ... in the  reactions of the nervous system...  to fear...  Fear?
Fear?
Fear.
CLOSE SHOT of the word 'fear'.
We are looking at the spine of a book on Mark's shelf. Th full title reads: The Physiology of Fear by Professor A.  N. Lewis.
Especially fear in children - and  how they react to it.
CLOSE SHOT of the word 'fear' on the next book.
The full title reads: FEAR AND THE NERVOUS SYSTEM, PART I PROFESSOR A. N. LEWIS.  There is a row of such books all  by Professor Lewis. CLOSE SHOT of Mark.

I think he learned a lot... from  me... I'd wake up... screaming...  sometimes... and he'd be there...  taking notes... and pictures...  and I'm sure good came of it...  for some people... He was brilliant.
A scientist drops a lizard onto a  child's bed - and good comes of  it?
I don't know... if he did... but  if he did... he'll have learned  something of value...
If only about lizards!  Mark - it  sounds to me as if your father  was...
He founded clinics.
He sounds completely...
He was famous! Professor A. N.  Lewis... three clinics.
Why do you still live in his  house... and watch his films?
They helped make me... what I am.
A photographer? It's no wonder, is  it? But you still haven't shown me  anything you've photographed!
He looks at her in silence.
Will you?
There is a knock on the door.
One day...
He hurries to the door, and opens it.  Tony is standing there.
Excuse me, but...
From Tony's POV WE SEE Helen looking at the door of the  dark room.
Oh, there you are, Helen.
She turns towards him.
The party looks like breaking up,  and we were wondering if...
I'm coming.
She turns to Mark.
I wish you'd join us.
Mark shakes his head.
Thanks... work.
I hope that you...
She is suddenly aware of Tony watching her. She glances a the birthday cake on the table.
... have a sweet tooth!
She smiles at him.
Thank you... for my present.
She goes into the passage.
Good night, old boy.
He puts his arm round Helen, and closes the door.  Mark stares after them, motionless. The CAMERA LINGERS on the birthday cake. As the light fades, a voice yells: Cut!

HIGH ANGLE SHOT of a set showing part of a large West End store. A blonde is lying unconscious in front of a lift - and a  crowd of extras surround her.  As the word 'cut' dies away, the extras relax - and the  blonde (DIANE ASHLEY) props herself onto her elbow, looki towards the Director. CLOSE SHOT of the Director (ARTHUR BADEN) standing beside the camera.
OK. Print that one!

He glances at the CHIEF CAMERAMAN (PHILIP TALE), who nods his head in agreement. CLOSE SHOT of Mark standing at the back of the camera cre He shakes his head in disagreement. The Chief Cameraman spots Mark's small mutiny and wags hi finger at him. As the Chief Cameraman turns away, Mark's  finger automatically wags back. CLOSE SHOT of Baden looking at his watch. He sighs, then  nods to the Assistant Director who stands beside him.
All right, everyone! Back at two!

Baden walks out without a word to anyone. A hubbub of  chatter breaks out. The unit downs tools and begins to  disperse. CLOSE SHOT of one of the extras (VIVIAN) - a small,  vivacious, brunette with delicate, attractive features. She edges towards the camera crew. CLOSE SHOT of Mark watching her. Over his shoulder WE SEE Vivian glance towards him. He  nods almost imperceptibly. Vivian hurries towards the exit. Mark turns to a shelf behind him - picks up his cine-came and a little full string bag containing his lunch.
CLOSE SHOT of Vivian munching a sandwich.

She is leaning against a wall in a corner of an exterior  set - a Chinese temple or a medieval castle (or a  combination of each like a Pinewood drawing-room).   Beside her she has a small tape-recorder, or record-playe We hear music - modem rhythms. There are several people strolling about - but no one in  the immediate vicinity. No one... except Mark.   CLOSE SHOT of Mark - settling down on the other side of  the wall (where they can talk without being seen together
Mark?
Hallo...
Were you spotted?
Don't think so.
(switches off music) Is it tonight?
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
Yes.
CLOSE SHOT of Vivian.
Mark...
Yes?
You're sure we won't be caught?
Not if you do as I tell you.
I will, I promise.
You haven't... said anything... to  anyone?
Of course not.
Good... like some cake?
Thank you.
We see him break off a piece of birthday cake, and pass i over to her.
Mark... I want to be quite clear  about this...
CLOSE SHOT of Mark staring at his cake.
Tonight, when the studio's empty...  I'm to come back-and you're going  to give me a film test... right?
Right.
You'll then print the film - so I  can show it to my agent and anyone  else who matters - right?
Right.
Mark...
She hesitates.
I've been offered film tests  before... but I haven't liked the  terms.
There aren't any.
Then why are you doing this? Risking  your job and...
Not just for you... Viv... I have  an agent too - and I want to show  him what I can do... I want to  direct...
(switching on music  again) There's someone coming.
Mark lies motionless behind the wall. A young male EXTRA  comes towards Vivian.
Hallo - lousy morning's work, wasn't  it?
Yes.
Thought I saw you talking to  somebody...
I was learning my lines.
Didn't know you had any...
He glances at his watch.
Want a drink? Dutch?
Later... perhaps.
Be seeing you
He wanders off.
Mark...
Yes?
(switching off music  again) You didn't mind me asking?
No, more cake?
No... you want to direct... more  badly than anything don't you?
Mark is silent, staring at the sky.
Don't you, Mark?
I want... to photograph... the  impossible...
What is impossible?
Something... that has never been  photographed before.
What?
You really want to know...?
Very much, especially if there's a  part for me.
I want... to photograph a murder...  while it's being committed.
No part for me then.
But that... isn't enough.
Is this a new script?
I want... to frighten... someone...  to death... and photograph... their  expression of fear...
Mark! What's this story called?
That is something... he never  photographed...
Who?
Mark is silent.
Who is he, Mark?
Anyone.
No one could... they'd be caught!
I wouldn't care... if I had my  picture.
Besides, how would you frighten  anyone to death?
There's a way.
Well, what?
There's a way.
You'd better not tell me! I'll be  scared to death tonight as it is!
A hooter.
Back on the set - shall I go first?
Please.
She rises to her feet. From behind the wall comes a gentl whirring purring sound.
What are you doing?
Getting into practice.
She smiles down at him.
See you tonight!
See you tonight!
She walks away. And the gentle purring continues. CAMERA  PANS to the sun beating down on the lot.
An arc lamp beating down on the set.
Baden bears down on the Assistant Director.
Would you enquire if our leading  lady is ready to start leading.
A cry goes up,
Miss Diane Ashley, please!...  Miss Diane Ashley, please!...
CLOSE SHOT of Baden turning towards the entrance. CLOSE SHOT of Mark turning towards the entrance. CLOSE SHOT of entrance.
Miss.  DIANE ASHLEY appears... among the many qualities  she radiates is goodwill - especially towards Miss Diane  Ashley.
How are you, Sparks? Chippy? Bob?
Hallo, Diane...
How are you, Tom? Roger?
Hallo, Diane...
And so on, until:
How are you, Phil?... Mark?
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
Hallo, Miss Ashley.
(to a figure high  in the scaffolding) How are you, Pete...?
Hi, Di!
She reaches Baden - and completely ignores him.
Darling, you've only been playing  this part for three weeks, so in  case you haven't yet had a chance  to read the script...
She ignores this.
... may I remind you that you're a  girl with an irresistible impulse!
She looks at him - then at her hand - and nods.
a kleptomaniac! Who cannot help  stealing... Get inside her,  Diane!... What - in all the world -  do you most want to steal?
The limelight!
Baden sighs.
We'll run the scene where you catch  sight of the store detective and  faint... Where's the girl who plays  the bystander?
Vivian steps forward.
How are you?
Hallo, Diane...
Positions, everyone!

CLOSE SHOT of Vivian taking her position in front of the  lift. She glances at her watch. CLOSE SHOT of Mark standing by the side of the studio  camera. He glances at his watch. CAMERA TRACKS towards the lift. From Mark's POV WE SEE Diane catch sight of the Store  Detective - and crumple in a faint.
Hit that floor with a thud!
CLOSE SHOT of door marked: DON JARVIS - MANAGING DIRECTOR
D.J. insists on realism!
A timid knock is overlaid before we dare enter.
CLOSE SHOT of a pile of scripts on a great man's desk.

MR. JARVIS is immersed in reading a script... his eyes  race across the page. Over his shoulder WE SEE what he is reading... a sheet of figures attached to the script. At the same time Mr. Jarvis is holding a telephone receiv to his ear - and we hear an enthusiastic VOICE FILTERED
...it's a wonderful subject, D.J....  Paramount wants it, M.G.M. wants  it, Columbia wants it.
But is it commercial?
Danny Angel wants it!
Still reading the script, Mr. Jarvis lays the receiver on his desk and picks up another.
Are those budgets ready? Well bring  'em in.
He replaces this receiver and picks up the original. The voice is still talking - something about 'a wonderful part for Kenny or Alec'...
Send me a memo - we'll discuss it  next week.

He replaces the receiver.  MISS SIMPSON enters. She hands him some folders... her smile curtsies.  CLOSE SHOT of Mr. Jarvis opening a folder. Over his shoulder WE SEE a page covered with row upon row of figures. The great man's finger skims along the figures like a tai feeling cloth.

There's an error!  The total should  be a hundred and fifty thousand  pounds fourteen shillings and  sixpence - not thirteen and  ninepence... That could mean the  difference between profit and loss  on a first feature!
Sorry, D.J.
He glowers at her - but his day is made.
Any units working late tonight?
Only one, sir. Night exteriors on  the lot. The Elephant with two...
That animal needs a stick of  dynamite!
CLOSE SHOT of Jarvis.
Remind me to pay them a visit  tonight.
Yes, D.J.
She makes a note in her little book.
Now, Miss Simpson... take a memo  to all department heads...
Over his shoulder WE SEE an open window. CAMERA TRACKS  towards it.
In light of the new economy drive...
CLOSE SHOT of Clapper Boy's board.  It reads: Take 49.
Again, please... and, darling...
He turns to Diane, who is wearily picking herself up off  the floor.
... just this once... will you  please make an effort to forget  that you're stunning, and try to  look as if you're stunned...?
Say one kind word - and I would  be!
(hastily) Positions, everyone!

Camera crew on a tracking shot. Mark is operating the Sel motor.   Baden - shaking his head.   Diane - picking herself up off the floor.   Clapper Boy's board  reading: Take 57.   Vivian - glancing at her watch.   Mark - glancing at his.   Diane - picking herself up off the floor.
If I have to faint once more I  shall faint!
CLOSE SHOT of Baden - triumphant at last.
Cut! How was that?... (thumbs up all round -  with one exception) Mark?
Mark nods perfunctorily.
Print it!
He glances at his watch - then nods to the Assistant  Director.
That's it, boys and girls . . .  wrap it up! Night-night everyone!  Baden puts his arm round Diane's  shoulder.
How are you, darling?

She makes a hobbling exit.   CLOSE SHOT of Vivian hurrying towards the exit carrying  her little recorder. In a burst of chatter, the unit starts to disperse. CLOSE SHOT of Mark picking up his cine-camera and his lun bag. The CLAPPER BOY comes up to him.
Catching the bus?
Not tonight... meeting someone...  for a drink.
Wanted to discuss the film at the  Everyman... Tomorrow then?
I hope so.
Good night, Mark.
Good night.
CLOSE SHOT of Vivian. She is sitting at a dressing-room  table... making-up with care.
Three other girls share the dressing room with her. There is a knock at the door - and the Young Extra who  spoke to Vivian in the grounds pokes his head round.
Greetings... lousy afternoon's  work, wasn't it? Who wants a lift  to town?
In what?
colleague's car... there's room  for two on my lap - three at a  pinch.
Which is what we'd get.
You, Viv?
No, thanks... I've a date... at  the Local.
Us two then?
I'm game... might as well get  pinched in a car as squeezed in a  tube.
The cars are streaming towards the gate.   CLOSE SHOT of Baden driving a small new car.   CLOSE SHOT of the Chief Cameraman driving a large old one
He is still immersed in his figures.   Miss Simpson is walking to the door. She glances at her  little book.
I'm to remind you to pay a surprise  visit tonight to The Elephant  with...
He grunts.
Good night, D.J.
Jarvis goes on reading...
CLOSE SHOT of Vivian.

Music playing. Vivian moves about nervously in front of a mirror in the deserted dressing room. She wears slacks an a shirt. She glances at her watch - her hands are trembli looks at watch, hears the fireman coming, then switches  off the music and hides in the big cupboard -
Fireman making his rounds, turning off lights.
Only a few cars now remain. It is beginning to grow dark.
The long corridors are dim and deserted.
The fireman is making his rounds.
Vivian is standing in the cupboard - the lights are on.
Fireman opening the dressing-room doors - and glancing  inside.
Two electricians are smoking.
Fireman opens the door of Vivian's dressing room.
From Vivian's POV WE SEE the lights go out. WE HEAR the sound of the door closing - and the Fireman's footsteps disappearing down the corridor.
The great man closing up his folder... glancing at his  watch... turning out the light.

Vivian is hurrying along a deserted corridor... and the  little recorder.   She pauses - and glances out of a door. She carries her case Over her shoulder WE SEE the studio  lot - in a blaze of light we can see a crowd of people  hanging about in solar topees and tropical kit.  REVERSE SHOT of Vivian watching anxiously.  She turns away - and hurries down the corridor.

Don Jarvis strides across the courtyard. We can almost  hear - and perhaps we do - a cash register ringing up. One of the white-clad figures lounging indolently in the  doorway glances round, sees the Inquisition approaching  and freezes. His degree of terror might satisfy Mark. The great man strides on.

Vivian pauses in front of the entrance to the set.   Above the note is a notice: 'NO ADMITTANCE WHILE RED LIGH IS ON'. The light is out.   Vivian looks round - there is no one in sight. Vivian slips in quietly, and closes the door behind her.
The set is in darkness. CLOSE SHOT of Vivian looking round.
(in a whisper) Mark...?

No reply.  Vivian hesitates... then edges slowly forward. Ahead of her are shadowy counters full of merchandise.  Beyond them is the door of the lift.   CLOSE SHOT of the studio camera and the Director's empty  chair beside it.   CLOSE SHOT of Vivian edging forward.
Mark...?

She reaches one of the counters - and leans against it,  looking around.   REVERSE ANGLE shot of Vivian. She is leaning against the  counter of the trunk department. Trunks and suitcases at  'greatly reduced prices' are piled behind her.   CLOSE SHOT of Vivian. She starts whistling nervously unde her breath. Very faintly overlaid is the sound of Mark whistling unde his. Vivian stops whistling - and so does Mark. She listens intently for a moment - then peers at her wat CLOSE SHOT of the watch on Mark's wrist. CLOSE SHOT of Vivian. She shivers suddenly... then looks  at her watch again. She hesitates... then turns towards  the exit, and starts to edge back. She trips over a cable and almost falls. Suddenly she is bathed in light. She wheels round. One of the big spots is beating down on her.
Mark...?
No sign of him. Overlaid is a gentle purring sound.  Wher are another light comes on, shining through her hair.
Mark!
The sound of his steps is overlaid.
Listen... we must...
His footsteps stop... she looks round.
Where are you?
His voice is quietly overlaid.
Here, Viv...
She wheels round. CLOSE SHOT of Mark sitting in the Director's chair. He is holding in his lap his cine-camera, and a black bag.   CLOSE SHOT of Vivian breathing quickly.
You frightened me!
He looks at her in silence.
Now listen... they're working late  on the lot.
I know. They're branched off this  stage - I'm using their juice.
He nods, staring at her intently.
We must call it off... someone's  bound to see us.
They might... (rising slowly) ... but they won't interrupt us  while we're filming... I've put  the red light on.
CLOSE SHOT of the red light - burning. CLOSE SHOT of Vivian.
You've what?...
Put the...
Then they'll know someone's here.
They won't come in.
They'll wait outside... what's the  difference?
The difference is... a perfect  film...
Over his shoulder WE SEE the studio camera.
... have waited... a long time...  for this... and so have you ... no  one... must interrupt it.
She glances round at the brazenly burning lights; shakes  her head despairingly.
We'll be caught.
What does that matter?
Matter!
You stand to lose... a job as an  extra... I stand to lose... nothing.
She looks at him in silence.
...the results must be so perfect...  that the risks don't count...
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
So perfect... that even he ... (he hesitates) ... even he... would say...
Who Don Jarvis!?
He looks at her, then nods.
Oh! He'd say: (imitating the great  man's voice) Sign on the dotted line, kiddies!  You can use my pen, but bring your  own ink! (her excitement is  growing) Mark... if you're sure it's worth  it?
It's time to find out, Viv...
He walks slowly towards the studio camera.   She prepares for the test by switching on music and warmi up with dance movements.
Come on! Get hot! (she accents the  rhythm)

Mark puts the cine-camera and the black cloth bag on the  dolly, slowly mounts the platform, closes the blimp - and swings the camera. We watch him from the top of the studio, from the door of the studio, from the Director's chair. And finally WE WAT HIM from Vivian's POV. She stops dancing but the music  continues.
You belong there...

He stares ahead of him, his mind far, far away... then  bends and looks into the finder.   There is a single harsh chord of music - and the screen  goes dark. It remains dark for a moment. Suddenly the darkness parts like curtains - and in the  centre WE SEE Vivian's face in the finder of the studio  camera. (Unlike the ground-glass of the newsagent's camer we see everything the right way up and in perfect  perspective.) Mark hooks a filler-light below the camera and switches i on. He adjusts the finder until he has made of Vivian's  delicate features a radiant miniature. The miniature smiles shyly at him. She has stopped dancin and is looking directly at the camera. Music continues.
I do feel alone in front of it... (she hesitates) I suppose stars never do?
They feel alone without it... (he looks in the  eyepiece)
Through the film, we can see only her eyes - large and  wistful.
... and the great ones... feel  alone... all the time...
She becomes the uninhibited Vivian again.
Then I'm great, boy! What is it  you want me to act? (she strikes an  attitude a, la  Rabbins)
He looks up from the camera; she smiles and starts keepin time to the rhythm again.
Being frightened to death?
You remembered?
Yes - and I'll have a go!
We hear his quick breathing.
I've been wondering all the  afternoon how you'd do it!  I'll  bet you've thought of a wonderful  twist! (she does a wonderful  twist)

CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He looks down - a little sadly - and  peers into the finder. (The camera dolly is on tracks - h tracks forward.) Music continues - piano.   In the finder WE SEE a large trunk - 'at greatly reduced  prices'  on the shelf behind Vivian. From Vivian's POV WE SEE Mark leave the studio camera   and hurry towards the trunks. She watches him wide-eyed.
What are you doing?
Building us a set.
He reaches for the largest trunk.
Why not pull the studio down while  you're about it? They can only  hang you once.
Exactly.

He carries the trunk towards the studio camera, and lays  it carefully on the floor. Music continues. Vivian peers into the front-glass of the studio camera   as if it were a mirror. The rhythm of the music changes.
If only Don Jarvis could see me  now!
She jumps onto the trunk and taps.
If only I could see Don Jarvis  now!
She giggles again.
I warn you, Mark - I'm hysterical...  I'd rather act dying of laughter,  if it's all the same to you...
She jumps off the trunk onto the floor. He opens the trunk. she jumps into it. Her laughter echoe round the deserted studio.
The two electricians are roaring with laughter. One of  them is making tea.
So he did it again! Now you tell  one.
CAMERA PANS to a dial on the wall... one of the needles  flickers slightly.
Half a mo...
One lump or two?
As the starlet said to the casting  director...
He turns away from the dials, and grasps at the outstretc mug.
CLOSE SHOT of Vivian recording - her little recorder is  twittering back at great speed.
(to Mark, over her  shoulder) What are you doing?
She restarts music.
She is watching Mark curiously as he arranges the lightin
Be patient, Viv... it's going to  be worth it.

CLOSE SHOT of the studio camera. In front of it - fixed o a small hook - is a tape measure. Mark reaches for it... then carefully measures the distan between the trunk and the camera... then he takes apiece  of chalk from his pocket and makes a small cross on the  floor. The music continues.
Oh well! I've stood alone in front  of a studio camera! That's more  than most have.
Ever stood... behind one?
He glances at a nearby dial - only a few feet away from  the one which is flickering.
No.
Help yourself.
She goes around the camera out of sight - and he is out o hers. He glances into the trunk - it is deep, and very  empty.
(accenting the rhythm) I can see you, Mark... perfectly!
Good...
Yes, sir! I'll bet I'm the best  camerawoman in the business! . . . (beating time with  her feet)
Mark hurries to the side of the studio camera and picks u his cine-camera.
I've lost you!
I'll be back.
Suddenly Mark's face appears in the finder.
Welcome, stranger!
We see Mark raise his cine-camera. He seems to be pointin it straight at us.  We hear a gentle purring.
What are you doing?
Photographing you photographing  me...
High angle shot of Mark standing in front of the studio  camera - photographing her photographing him.
(in mock awe) Mark, you're brilliant...
He walks slowly towards her, holding his cine-camera to  his eyes.  In the finder of Mark's cine-camera WE SEE Viv at the studio camera. She comes closer and closer.
Lost you again!
Never mind.
We see him standing almost on top of her - his cine-camer trained on her.
I'm ready now, Viv...
She looks up slowly - and a little hesitantly. Music, all drums.
Go and stand on that cross, will  you?
(solemnly) Yes, sir, Mr. Director, sir.
He watches her in silence as she walks to the front of th studio camera and takes up her position. while the drum- beat continues.

Don Jarvis is leaving the unit working on the lot. It is  now bustling with activity. A girl comes up to him... She raises her cigarette for a  light - and looks into his eyes.   He hands her a box of matches... and walks away.  Over hi shoulder we see the other stages - apparently empty. Don  Jarvis hesitates, then strides towards one.
CLOSE SHOT of a dial - the needle flickering slightly.  Overlaid is the voice of the 1st Electrician.
...and here's one of the wife and  nipper...
CLOSE SHOT of Vivian staring at the trunk on the floor  behind her. The recorded rhythm continues.
Am I supposed to imagine someone  is going to put me in there?

Yes, Viv...
He peers into the viewfinder. In the finder we see Vivian looking rather pathetically into camera.
Mark - I hope I won't let you  down... I know you're trying to  create atmosphere for me - but...  I just don't feel frightened!  Wouldn't it be better if I just  did my number?
(shaking head) Later.
Oh all right! I could do anything -  I feel so relaxed - and that's due  to you... You're so at home with  that camera you make me feel at  home too... you have it in you,  boy!
From her POV WE SEE see him raise his head slightly.
Ready, Viv?
(great effort) Well-I'll try -
In the finder we see her wrinkling her brow.
But what... would... frighten me  to death? (looking appealingly  into camera) Set the mood for me, Mark...
Well...
He goes and switches off the recorder. The sudden silence is startling.
Imagine someone... coming towards  you... who's going to kill you -  regardless of consequences...
A madman?
Yes - but he knows it... and you  don't... and just to kill you...  isn't enough for him.
But how would he frighten me to?
She stares into focusing screen - intrigued, but not  frightened, not even by the silence and shadowy vastness  around her.
Stay there, Viv... you're... just  right.
She stands motionless - staring into camera.

CLOSE SHOT of Don Jarvis. He is standing motionless, star down a corridor. What he is staring at is out of camera - and it is puzzli the great man. He walks quietly along the corridor.  CLOSE SHOT of Vivian.
I can't imagine what you've thought  of!

CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He raises his head slowly - and locks the studio camera off. Then he walks slowly towards her. HIGH ANGLE SHOT of Mark walking towards Vivian. CAMERA ZOOMS DOWN to the trunk behind her. Mark's voice i overlaid:
Suppose this... were one of his  weapons...

The great man is poised for the kill. He is moving forwar stealthily... and suddenly breaks into a run.  CAMERA PANS - and WE SEE the object of his attentions. Smoking on duty!
The Fireman opens his mouth to explain  and smoke exudes.
Come with me!

That..?

CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He is holding his cine-camera; fixed to it is a collapsib tripod.  Suddenly he pulls one leg of the tripod out. WE SEE that very sharp spike protrudes from the end of it. From Mark's POV WE SEE Vivian looking at the spike. He raises it towards her - until the spike is only inches from her throat.

But... there's something else...
We can hear his heart pounding as if it will burst - and  gradually Vivian, too, becomes aware of it.
Well? What is it?
Just for a moment Mark's arm moves. His back hides what h is doing. Suddenly WE SEE Vivian turn her head sharply -  she is looking at something out of camera.
(in a whisper) That...?
The spike is very close to her throat - but Vivian ignore it, staring out of camera. Over Mark's shoulder we concentrate on Vivian's face.
(in a whisper) Mark... take it...
The fear on her face is rapidly growing...
... away!
She tries to move back - but the trunk prevents her.
MARK - YOU!

It is almost a scream. We can hear Mark breathing quickly.  Vivian raises her hands to push something away from her. Suddenly the screen is filled with her eyes. WE SEE them  dilating with terror. There is a sudden crash as the big  power switches go out in the roof. The lights go out. There is a scream in the darkness. Then silence. The darkness acquires a grey, opaque quality as if one is seeing the world through a curtain - it is the world of  Mrs. Stephens.   A bright light is felt, rather than seen, beating against our eyelids. It looms closer and stronger.
And that, darling, is the end of  the news! Unless you want the  football results?
CLOSE SHOT of Mrs. Stephens, a large glass of whisky - an the bottle - beside her. It is night.
No thank you.
CLOSE SHOT of Helen. 'She's Got the Key of the Door' is  overlaid.
What else can I read you?
The label on this whisky bottle!   Are you sure it says seventy per  cent proof?
Certain.
They're bigger liars than the press!
From Helen's POV WE SEE her reach for her glass with a  steady hand.
Is that your last tonight?
I doubt it.
Your last but one?
Don't haggle.
(producing a coin) Toss me double or nothing?
Done!
Helen spins the coin on the table Mrs. Stephens listens  intently... the coin stops spinning.
Heads.
Her fingers shoot out and feel the surface of the coin.
Bad luck, darling.
Huh.
She turns the coin over and carefully feels the other sid Helen watches her with a smile - then looks thoughtfully  at the ceiling.
What are you looking at?
The ceiling!
Wondering if that young man is  home?
Yes.
Well he is... I heard him come  in... four paragraphs ago.
From Helen's POV WE SEE the sightless eyes staring at her
Do you like him?
CLOSE SHOT of Helen.
Yes, darling.
Why?
He has a quality...
(sipping her glass) Wish this had.
... and I think he could help me.
With your photographs?
Yes...
CLOSE SHOT of Mrs. Stephens.
Helen...
Yes?
Mrs. Stephens hesitates - which is rare.
(abruptly) It doesn't matter.
(quickly) Mummy, what's worrying you?
The price of whisky.
What else?
What else matters?
Don't you like Mark?
Haven't met him.
You don't like him! Now why not?
CLOSE SHOT of Mrs. Stephens. Again she hesitates.
I distrust a man who walks quietly.
He's shy!
His footsteps aren't! They're  stealthy...
Now darling.
Are you going up to him?
May I?
We both have the key of the door...  Mine needs oiling - and yours needs  exercise... Off you go.
Thank you.
She kisses her - and glances at the whisky glass.
remember that you lost the toss.
She walks to the door.
Helen...
Yes, darling?
If you're back in five minutes...  I won't even finish this.
Done!
She hurries out. Mrs. Stephens instantly refills her glas CLOSE SHOT of her hand. It has begun to tremble.

CLOSE SHOT of Mark's hands, in the green light of the dar room. He is busy unloading and winding film onto a  developing rack. He puts the rack of exposed film into the tank and starts the time clock. CLOSE SHOT of the time clock ticking. A knock is heard off. Mark looks up.
Who is it?
Helen...
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.  Faintly overlaid is 'She's Got the  Key of the Door'.  He looks down at the clock.
(calling) Come in, Helen!
Helen opens the door of Mark's sitting room. We hear Mark call out from the inner room:
Would you... please... wait in  there?... Developing.
Helen goes in, closing the door behind her.
Helen enters. She speaks loudly to be heard in the dark- room.
Mother heard you come in - so I  guessed you wouldn't be in bed ...
No reply from the inner room.
Are you sure this is conven...
Won't be long!

Helen glances at her watch... then looks curiously round  the room. CLOSE SHOT of Vivian's recorder, placed on a chair. CLOSE SHOT of Helen. She picks it up and looks at it,  curiously, fingering the stops.
Hallo.
Helen turns round. Mark is standing on the threshold of  the dark-room.
Hallo, Mark...
He walks towards her... he stops suddenly. He is staring  at the recorder in her hand.
I hope you don't mind - is it a  tape-recorder?
Yes.
Gently he takes it from her - as if it is a cup with whic she has finished - and replaces it on the shelf. CLOSE SHOT of Helen.
I'm sure I'm being a nuisance...  but, Mark, I very much want to...
Her voice trails away. CLOSE SHOT of Mark. He is holding out a small package.
Happy birthday.
Mark! That's very sweet of you -  but really.
It isn't much... I don't know  anything about... presents for  twenty-one... but I saw it this  morning... so... please.
(gently) Thank you...
She takes the package, and unwraps it. Inside is a slende brooch
It's beautiful...
I like the design... More milk?
More?... No, thank you, Mark...  and I really appreciate this...  I'm going to put it on now.

There?... Or there?...
The first place...

CLOSE SHOT of Helen pinning it on.  CLOSE SHOT of Mark touching his lapel.  CLOSE SHOT of Helen glancing at her watch.   CLOSE SHOT of Mark glancing at his. He thinks of the tick clock in the dark-room.   Helen looks up, and sees him.

From me?  Please...

He looks as if he has just been voted the best cameraman  of the year (unanimously) - and the two films he directed have both won Oscars (though Don Jarvis understood them). His delighted astonishment is such that she has to smile.
... I work in a public library -  in the children's section... I'm  telling you that to postpone  admitting what always embarrasses  me...
She takes a deep breath.
In my spare time... I write.
What's embar...
I write stories for children...  but so did Grimm... Hans Andersen...  Lewis Carroll...
Had any published?
Some short stories.
I'd like to read...
I learned today... that my first  book... has been accepted! ... For  publication in the spring...
But that's wonderful... what's it  about?
A magic camera - and what it  photographs...
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
Whatever made you... think of that?
I'll tell you one day - I promise...
Well what does it photograph?

I'll tell you that too - but,  Mark... this is the problem... The  children who read the book will  want to see the pictures the camera  takes - but the publishers say  they're impossible to photograph,  and suggest drawings... but I don't  agree.
No - nothing's impossible.
was hoping you'd say that! There  must be photographs - however  difficult to take - and I was  wondering, Mark - if you'd...
Oh yes.
discuss it with me.
take them.

I'd take them... for you.

There are some things... which I  photograph... for nothing.
I didn't mean to offend you.
Offend?
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
Helen... if you knew what it  meant... for something to happen  to me... that I don't have to make  happen... it's like... you've given  me a twenty-first birthday...
CLOSE SHOT of Helen looking at him...
What does your camera photograph?
Mark - I must go... I just wanted  to know... if you'd talk it over  with me.
When please?
That's up to you.
Helen ... I don't know much about...  dinner out... but would you come  with me?
Thank you.
Thank you.
When?
Oh...
What's the matter?
It had better be soon...
Are you going away?
Almost for certain! ...
Oh... well you suggest when.
Are you free... tomorrow night?
Yes.
I hope I am!
I'll understand if you're not.
I'll try to be - I'll try my hardest  to be.
Thank you for listening... and for  my present.
and for mine.
They look at each other in silence.
Good night, Mark... (turning to the  door)
Good night... Helen...
He watches her leave, standing very still. Offstage, the time clock explodes. CLOSE SHOT - the excited clock. Mark's hand silences it.

CAMERA PANS across Baden's disgruntled face... the Chief  Cameraman's bored face... the Script Girl's puzzled face. to Diane's expression of rapture as she watches herself o the screen.
I'd like to see that one.

From Diane's POV WE WATCH the screen. We see the Tall Man (SHOP ASSISTANT) reaching for a trunk and laying it on th counter. He opens it with a flourish. Vivian passes acros the screen - glances casually at the trunk - and wanders  off.
No - no - no - we must get some  comedy into this...!
The Assistant Director nods.

CAMERA LINGERS for a moment on the screen as Diane (on- screen) smiles at the Assistant.
(she pockets a small  item) I'll take it.

The Assistant is leaning over the counter, listening  intently. Diane stands in front of the counter, receiving the attentions of the Make-up Man.   Baden's voice is overlaid:
I want some comedy in this scene...

The unit is busy preparing for a retake. The studio camer (and its crew) are off camera, and we concentrate on Bade briefing his artistes.   He is clutching a script as if afraid that opening it mig be indecent exposure.

Instead of taking the first trunk  you see, I want you, darling... to  ask for a blue trunk - and when he  brings it to you, to ask for a red  one - and when he brings that, to  ask for a white one... (turns to the  Assistant) And you, Michael... get the trunks  one by one - growing more and more  fed up - and we'll end on a gag  which I'll think of in a minute -  all right?
I don't feel it!
Don't feel it! Do it!
(hastily) Positions, everyone!
Over Mark's shoulder - behind the camera - WE WATCH the  Unit taking up positions.
Anyone seen Vivian?
Who?
The red-headed bystander - Viv.
(impatiently) Never mind - I'm cutting her out  of this scene... Let's run it.
(shouting) Quiet, everyone!
From Mark's POV WE WATCH the scene being rehearsed. Diane approaches the trunk counter and the Assistant smiles at  her.
Can I interest you in a trunk?
Thank you... (pointing) I'd like to see that one...
Certainly, madam...
He turns away. She pockets a small item from the counter. He heaves a trunk forward.
It's beautifully fitted - (he opens it)
She takes a perfunctory glance -
I'd like to see one in red.
Certainly, madam.
She pockets another item.  He turns and wrestles with  another trunk... brings it forward and opens it
... do you have one in white?
Certainly, madam.
Mark walks away quietly from the back of the Camera Crew. He hurries to the shelf where he keeps his cine-camera an a lunch basket. He reaches for his camera.   Diane's voice is overlaid.
Do you have one in blue?
Certainly, madam...

Mark turns towards the rehearsal and raises his cine-came WE SEE the Assistant try to lift a blue trunk - and half  collapse with the weight of it. CLOSE SHOT of Baden - beaming. The Assistant manages to drag the trunk forward. He leans over it - exhausted - then starts to open it. Mark moves round until Diane's face is in the finder. As the lid of the trunk is opened we can see only her eye above the rim of the lid... WE HEAR her scream. CLOSE SHOT of Baden - freezing.   There is the sound of a body falling to the ground.
The silly bitch! She's fainted in  the wrong scene...
In the darkness WE HEAR a telephone ringing... and then  another... and then another... then they all merge into  one big blast.
CAMERA TRACKS quickly towards a door marked PUBLICITY  DEPARTMENT.
The Head of publicity has a receiver to his ear.

is this a gag?... A girl in a  trunk!... Who is she?... Well,  which unit?... The walls are closing  in?... What a break for them!... I  mean what a heartbreak! (he is already  speaking into  another telephone) call a press conference. (he turns to the  original telephone) I'm on my way down!
A police car. There are two men seated at the back.
CHIEF INSPECTOR GREGG is reading a file. A plain-clothes  SERGEANT (MILLER) is seated next to him. The Sergeant  glances at his Chief apprehensively.
Excuse me, Chief.
Mm?
We pass my house when we reach the  bypass. Would you mind if I drop  off for a minute?
(without raising  his eyes) To collect your kid's autograph  book?
Yes, Chief!... If the nipper hears  where I've been...
(turns to the driver) All right, Dawson - anything to  help the Sergeant... (stares down at the  folder) ... and it's about time the Sergeant  helped me - we're getting nowhere  with this.
Over his shoulder WE SEE what he is looking at - it is a  photograph of Dora in her furs and finery.
What about that man the landlady  passed?
She couldn't describe him - except  to say that he was carrying  something that she couldn't see.
That's a help.
CLOSE SHOT of the Inspector staring at the folder.
Sergeant, I've been on the force  thirty odd years... and I have  never seen such fear on anyone's  face as on this girl's... (almost to himself) What was it she saw?
Surely, Chief... a man coming at  her - with a sharp weapon.
I'm familiar with that kind of  terror. This is something new to  me... but what?
The Sergeant glances at Dora's photograph.
...now take a look at how we found  her.
He starts to turn the page
A door with a sign on it: CANTEEN CLOSED TODAY.  CAMERA TRACKS TOWARDS it.

Mark is sitting by an open window at the far end of the  canteen. His cine-camera and lunch basket are by his side From Mark's POV WE SEE that the unit (with the exception  of Diane and Baden) is crowded into the canteen. They have formed themselves into small groups and are  talking in whispers.  The Assistant Director is standing  with his back to the door. A GIRL calls out:
How much longer must we wait in  here?
Till the police arrive... D.J.'s  orders.

and when she opened that trunk...  and I saw what was inside... my  dears - I nearly fainted with her - (he runs a delicate  hand across a  delicate forehead) and do you know what horrified me  most?
D.J. says not to discuss it.
Any more sauce from D.J. and I  shall refuse to sign for seven  years! My dears... that poor girl's  expression.

Mark glances out of the window. From his POV WE SEE a police car driving across the  courtyard. Mark watches with great interest - then reache for his cine-camera. He photographs the police, then puts his cine-camera on t the table and sits back... waiting. CAMERA LINGERS for a  moment on the folded tripod.

The set is completely deserted. It is lit by a single lam A solitary trunk stands on the counter, its lid closed.   WE SEE Don Jarvis enter, followed by the two Policemen.  Baden and the Publicity man bring up the rear. Don Jarvis points towards the trunks department. The Chie Inspector nods, then he and the Sergeant approach the  counter. Carefully the Inspector raises the lid of the trunk - he  looks inside. CLOSE SHOT of the Inspector - over the top of the lid. Hi expression is mainly one of surprise. (in a whisper) Chief, it's exactly the...

I know... (he closes the trunk  quickly. Quietly) ... don't say anything. (he faces Don Jarvis) Well, sir... we shall probably  have to interview everyone at the  studio, so we'd better plan a  campaign that won't interfere too  much with your productions.
(warming to him at  once) Thank you, Chief Inspector... if  you knew what even a single day's  delay could cost.
Oh, we do sir. (his eyes are on  the trunk)
CLOSE SHOT of Mark.
He is looking out of the window - his camera at the ready Overlaid is the sound of a door opening... the buzz of  conversation dies away. We hear Don Jarvis' voice.
If I may have your attention,  please.

A hand tugs at Mark's elbow. He turns round. The Clapper  Boy looks at him waringly. From Mark's POV WE SEE Don Jarvis standing in the doorway facing a suddenly hushed room. The great man's hands are  folded in front of him -
The police wish to interview each  of you individually... after which  you will be at liberty to leave.
From D.J.'s POV WE SEE the upturned faces - the light fro the window falls upon Mark, listening to him with rapt  attention. Mark's hands are folded in front of him.
There will, of course, be no  shooting today... but work will be  resumed, as usual, tomorrow...  with, I hope, all of you present.

I look to you to give the police  your fullest cooperation. (he turns abruptly  and leaves')
Sergeant Miller enters with a smile.

Well now... let's get ourselves  organized... (taking a piece of  paper from his  pocket) We don't want to keep you cooped  up in here, so we've worked out a  timetable... We'll talk to the  artists first, then the technicians  in this order...

The Young Extra who spoke to Vivian in the exterior set  points excitedly to the wall where Vivian and Mark lay.   The Inspector and Sergeant carefully examine both sides o the wall. ...she said she didn't want a lift -  because she had a call to make  locally.

Yes, sir ...
The Policemen and the Extra are walking away from camera  down a passage. A few members of other units pass them by without a glance. One of these (A GIRL) smiles into camer
Hallo, Mark...
Hallo.

As the Inspector opens the door of the dressing room, Mar hurries past. He raises his cine-camera and photographs  the Sergeant. The Sergeant turns to close the door. He  sees Mark. straightens his tie and looks as severe as he  can.

Sorry, sir.
He hurries down the passage.
(turning round) Do what?
Make me famous. Some chap was giving  me a screen test

The door of the small office opens - and the Chief Camera comes out.

You're next.
The Crew-member hurries into the office, and closes the  door. The Chief Cameraman wanders off thoughtfully.   Mark and the Clapper Boy are left sitting side by side.
I've been watching you...
Oh?
Have you been filming those  policemen?
Yes, I've a few quite interesting  shots of them - it's a chance I  never expected!
A chance for what?
To photograph... an investigation...  or as much of it as I can.
What on earth for?
It will complete a documentary I'm  making.
documentary?
Mark nods.
What's it about?
I'd rather not tell you till it's  finished. And it soon will be ...

Don't you mind?
No.
But they might confiscate your  camera.

I don't...
The door of the small room opens, and the Crew-member com out.
You, Mark?

Mark, hadn't you better leave that  with me?

I'd look after it.
I'm sure of that - but I'd like to  photograph them while they're  questioning me.
The Clapper Boy looks at him in amazement.
I don't suppose they'll let me.
Mark, are you potty?
