Don't get into any trouble for  heaven's sake  I want to discuss  that film at the Everyman...
Yes... I'd like that...
He walks slowly towards the door. The Clapper Boy takes out a copy of Sight and Sound and  starts to read it.

The Inspector is seated at a desk, reading some notes. Th Sergeant is seated by the side of the desk, a pile of pap in front of him. There is a gentle knock on the door. The Sergeant glances at a list.
Mark Lewis - focus-puller...  Whatever that may be?
The Inspector nods.
Come in.
He puts a tick on the list. There is the sound of a door  opening. The Inspector looks up... From his POV WE SEE a young man with a camera over his  shoulder advancing shyly towards him.
Mr. Lewis?
Yes, sir...
I'm Chief Inspector Gregg and this  is Sergeant Miller. Grab a chair.
The Sergeant glances up.
Ah! My photographer.
I've brought the camera in case  you want to take the film away.
He holds out his camera.  The Sergeant glances enquiringl at the Inspector.

Thank you, sir.
Well now; have you anything to  tell us?
Don't think so, sir.

Yes, sir...
How well?
Mainly by sight.

No, sir ... but a few things seem  to point to it... No one outside  your unit admits to knowing the  girl... There was a trunk all ready  for her... and with the risks he  was running, I think he'd have to  use surroundings he was familiar  with... Where is your unit now?
Waiting for me on the set.

I'm afraid it is, sir... now where  could I get the best view?

hope it's D.J. It's about time  they caught up with him!

philia... The morbid urge to gaze...  Coined since his day... Have you  any manuscripts of his which I  could...?

Usually. Now about his manuscripts -
Quickly?

... if you've any of his papers on  the subject?

Can't wait to show you this! (bringing out a  small postcard) I ought to charge you!

You don't get that in Sight and  Sound - Isn't she terrific?  Got  some more - if you're interested?
Mark hands it back.
You've given me... an idea...
I'll bet I have!
Mark turns towards the exit.
Hey! Where are you going?
Phone - may be my last chance -  and... thanks.

You have it!
He hurries excitedly towards the exit... CLOSE SHOT of the Clapper Boy staring at his photograph.
... some photograph! Well lit too!
He reaches for the lunch basket, then walks towards the  exit where the Sergeant is waiting casually.
Mark is talking at a coin-box telephone.
Can't manage Saturday, sir, but  they're letting us off early today!  This afternoon - after work - may  be my last chance!
While Mark is talking he is scribbling on a form. He has  some more pennies ready for the coin-box.
... be here at six o'clock. Milly'll  be waiting.
Six o'clock...
On the dot, Mark, or she'll go.
I'll be there, sir.
You'd better be!
Mark rings off. He is smiling. He puts in another 4d (Fou Pence) and dials a number. His pen is poised over the for he is filling in.
Hallo? Is that the Public Library?   ... You have a Miss Helen Stephens  employed there?  Yes... can you  tell me if her name is spelt with  a V or a PH, I want to send her a  tic-PH? ... Thank you.
We see the form is a last will and testament.  I, Mark  Lewis, etc., etc., leave, etc., etc., to Miss Helen Ste- ens all my worldly goods, etc.  He fills in PH.
The door bursts open and the Clapper Boy appears.
They're waiting!
CLOSE SHOT of Dr. Rosen smiling.

The Inspector and Doctor are standing by the bushes where Mark and Vivian met.

think so... we had a little chat  about scoptophilia - and he's going  to show me...

Voyeurism.
Eh?
What makes people into Peeping  Toms, one of his father's subjects,  apparently.
(slowly) Peeping Toms...
An interesting boy... he has his  father's eyes... you don't suspect  him, do you?
I suspect 'em all - what about  you?
I'm interested in that chap with  the bald head and hatchet face...  there's something on his mind!

CLOSE SHOT of Baden glancing at his watch... He whispers  to the Assistant Director.

went up to look around - found  her.

Not...
Leave!
Not... (she turns away  from him and forces  the words out) ... till I know...
Now!
She stands with her back to him. From REVERSE ANGLE we se her struggling for breath. Over her shoulder WE SEE him  staring at the 16mm screen.
That film...

That film...

... horrible ... horrible... but...  just a film... isn't it?

She stands motionless.

Your room.

Tony's.

(quietly) Turn it off!

Look at me!

What did you do... to those girls?
No.

... frightened ... for you...

He stands next to her, and looks at his long array of  cameras. WE SEE that each one of them has been fitted wit a small metal disc (a delayed release), and that some of  the older cameras have flashlights attached.
Watch them, Helen... Watch them  say goodbye - one by one - (he presses a master  switch on the wait) I've timed this... so often...

Slowly he walks past his cameras. As he does, the metalli disc on each one explodes with a little plop - and the ey of each camera winks once as if in salute. Some go off  with flashlights on either side of the room. The sound of footsteps hurrying up the stairs. Ahead of Mark - coming steadily closer  are the spikes of the tripod. Heavy shoulders are pressing against the dark-room door.. as it breaks in, Mark lunges forward against the spikes.  The cine-camera is wrenched away from the wall as he fall back. He crashes against the small table, which falls ove He is not parted from his camera - it is fixed to him by  the tripod, and falls back with him, covering his face  like a canopy.
